tv.source-info-name: Pluto TV Space guide by TV

programme.title: Inside Outer Space: Episode 5: Space Missions
programme.desc: Come with us as we explore and unravel the mysteries of what lies beyond our planet Earth. This is a series packed with space stories and information about our universe covering what we can see.

programme.title: Inside Outer Space: Episode 6: Fermi paradox
programme.desc: Come with us as we explore and unravel the mysteries of what lies beyond our planet Earth. This is a series packed with space stories and information about our universe covering what we can see.

programme.title: Inside Outer Space: Episode 7: The Milky Way
programme.desc: Come with us as we explore and unravel the mysteries of what lies beyond our planet Earth. This is a series packed with space stories and information about our universe covering what we can see.

programme.title: Inside Outer Space: Episode 8: Extravehicular Activity
programme.desc: Come with us as we explore and unravel the mysteries of what lies beyond our planet Earth. This is a series packed with space stories and information about our universe covering what we can see.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Windows to Other Worlds
programme.desc: As technology has advanced, we have been able to peer into distant reaches of space. From the first telescopes to high-tech satellites, these machines have been our windows to other worlds.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Fountain of Creation
programme.desc: Without the Sun's warmth and light, life as we know it would not exist. It is the powerhouse of our planet and provides the energy we need to survive.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Rocky Shores
programme.desc: The arid shores of other planets tell the stories of their past. What did they look like, and could they have ever supported life?

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Silent Partner
programme.desc: Although we have put man on the moon, our silent partner still holds many mysteries. What haven't we seen? What haven't we discovered?

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Borderland
programme.desc: Deserts and dunes, cliffs and canyons. Although Mars is certainly an alien wasteland, it is a planet with terrestrial formations remarkably similar to those found on Earth.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Mars: Red Dawn
programme.desc: Landing a spacecraft on Mars is no easy task given our limited knowledge of the planet. The difference between success and failure can rely on the most minute detail.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: The Giant Planets: Lords of Gravity
programme.desc: Gravity is one of the most basic and powerful forces shaping our universe. Discover its nature within our own solar system, from the smallest moons to the largest planets.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Outer Limits: Edge of the Solar System
programme.desc: For centuries, it was was thought that Saturn was the most distant planet in our Solar System. With the evolution of the telescope, we discovered the rest of our planets, both elusive and mysterious.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Hidden Havens: Icy Moons
programme.desc: There are hundreds of moons in our solar system. Could one of them be a hidden haven that harbors alien life forms?

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Icy Gems: Frozen Moons
programme.desc: In the far depths of space, out of reach of the Sun's warmth, water can only exist in a super solid state. Some small moons, in fact, are made entirely of ice. What stories do these Icy Gems have to tell about our solar system?

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Shooting Gallery: Asteroids and Comets
programme.desc: Scientist long thought that our solar system consisted of the sun, the planets, and their moons. We soon found that we are far from alone, often coming into contact with asteroids, comets, and other debris.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Galactic Visions: Alien Worlds
programme.desc: The diversity, complexity, and downright beauty of our own solar system is astounding. Could such beauty exist in other parts of the universe as well? Thanks to modern science, we now have the capability to see for ourselves.

programme.title: The Fabric of the Cosmos: The Illusion of Time
programme.desc: Brian Greene takes us on the ultimate time traveling adventure, hurtling 50 years into the future before stepping into a wormhole to travel back to Big Bang.

programme.title: The Fabric of the Cosmos: Quantum Leap
programme.desc: Join Brian Greene on a wild ride into the weird realm of quantum physics, which governs the universe on the tiniest of scales.

programme.title: The Fabric of the Cosmos: What Is Space?
programme.desc: Brian Greene reveals space as a dynamic fabric that can stretch, twist, warp, and ripple under the influence of gravity, and explores dark energy, which makes up 70% of the universe.

programme.title: The Fabric of the Cosmos: Universe or Multiverse?
programme.desc: Cutting-edge theories are suggesting that our universe may not be the only universe. Instead, it may be just one of an infinite number of worlds that make up the multiverse.

programme.title: In the Shadow of the Moon
programme.desc: Between 1968 and 1972, the world watched in awe each time an American spacecraft voyaged to the Moon. Only 12 men walked upon its surface and they remain the only human beings to have stood on another world.

programme.title: The Apollo Experience: Apollo 17: Part 1
programme.desc: Between 1960 and 1972, mankind boldly went where no human had been before. Across 11 manned missions, 24 men flew to the moon and 12 walked upon its surface. This film documents Apollo 17 through the eyes of the astronauts who flew.

programme.title: The Apollo Experience: Apollo 17: Part 2
programme.desc: In this episode, hear first hand testimonials and dialogue from the incredible men who walked on the moon. Incredible footage and photos give a unique and beautiful experience of their data collection process and journey home.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas
programme.desc: See the sun, moon, planets, and galaxies through the eyes of intrepid machines that are blazing a trail across the solar system. A gateway to bold adventures, these cameras are delivering spectacular new cosmic vistas.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Hubble's Renaissance
programme.desc: Before we can reach space, we must first be able to see it. Hundreds of years ago, the simple telescope was used to give us a seemingly closer vantage. Today, we use the awe-inspiring, and super powerful, Hubble Space Telescope.
